post: 📜  #OTD in 1838, Frederick Douglass boarded a northbound train from Baltimore, taking the courageous step that secured his freedom and launched his lifelong work for equality and justice. How can his story help students consider the meaning of liberty? 🔗 Lesson:  https://bit.ly/48hc2hS  #TDiH  #AmericanHistory  #CivicEducation

Stop by booths 408, 410, and 412 for live demos of our classroom games at  #NCSS2025. Experience how our resources help students practice civic reasoning in fun, meaningful ways. Sign up for updates + free materials:  https://lnkd.in/eVcfCStV  #CivicEducation  #GameBasedLearning  #SocialStudies

Students nationwide are sharing their civic-impact stories through the MyImpact Challenge. If you know a student making a difference, encourage them to take the next step. Learn more:  https://bit.ly/3fyGGr3  #MyImpactChallenge  #YouthLeadership  #CivicEngagement  #ServiceLearning

Join the Institutes team at  #NCSS2025! Three sessions led by our educators explore fresh, practical strategies for using primary sources and supporting civil discourse: • Tortured Historians Society: Strategies for Engaging Middle Schoolers with Primary Sources – Fri 3 PM (144A) • HOT TO GO!: Rapid-Fire Primary Source Strategies for Elementary History – Sat 8:30 AM (152A) • Rhythms of Dialogue – Sat Poster Session (Hall D, Table 16) See details + sign up for free resources:  https://bit.ly/4oqRng4  #CivicEducation  #TeachingHistory  #ProfessionalLearning

#NCSS2025 is this week! Visit us at booths 408, 410, and 412 to connect with our team, explore our K-12 civics resources, and learn how we support teachers nationwide. Register for updates + free resources:  https://bit.ly/4oqRng4  #CivicEducation  #TeachingResources  #SocialStudies

A new month brings a clean slate. Teachers: log 1 quick, A250-aligned activity and your class is instantly entered in Decembers Civic Star drawings. Whats 1 small civics connection youre planning this week? 🔗  https://bit.ly/3V1CQuX  #CivicStarChallenge  #CivicEducation  #America250  #TeachingResources  #K12

📜  #OTD in 1955, Rosa Parks refused to surrender her bus seat in Montgomery. Her quiet but resolute stand helped spark the Montgomery Bus Boycott and reshaped the modern civil rights movement. How can this moment help students reflect on courage and civic responsibility? 🔗 Lesson:  https://bit.ly/3JJmmn7  #TDiH  #RosaParks  #CivilRights  #CivicEducation

These Constitutions go very fast! Feedback from principals, teachers, and parents has been extremely positive as they encourage kids to learn and truly understand the scope & spirit of our founding documents.   John B., Pennsylvania educator Join the momentum: $1 = 1 copy ➡️  https://bit.ly/40EsBAg  #CivicsChampion  #CivicEducation  #TeacherVoices  #SupportTeachers  #CivicEngagement

This Thanksgiving, the Bill of Rights Institute is especially grateful for teachers who help students connect gratitude, community, and civic identity to the American story. For a deeper look at the themes behind the first Thanksgiving, listen to our Fabric of History podcast:  https://bit.ly/3CLy6yj  #Thanksgiving  #CivicEducation  #TeachingHistory

📜  #OTD in 1770, the trial of eight British soldiers involved in the Boston Massacre began. Defended by John Adams, the case tested the principle of due process, even amid public outrage. How can this moment help students discover justice under the rule of law? 🔗 Lesson:  https://bit.ly/49Cp2gK  #TDiH  #BostonMassacre  #RuleOfLaw  #CivicEducation  #CivicVirtues
